infodynamics.measures.continuous

Class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov

    public abstract class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
extends java.lang.Object
implements MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
    Implements MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate to provide a base class with common functionality for child class implementations of MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate via various estimators.

    These various estimators include: e.g. box-kernel estimation, KSG estimators, etc (see the child classes linked above).

    Usage is as outlined in MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.

    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • dimensionsSource

        protected int dimensionsSource
        Number of dimenions for our source multivariate data set

      • dimensionsDest

        protected int dimensionsDest
        Number of dimenions for our destination multivariate data set

      • sourceObservations

        protected double[][] sourceObservations
        The set of source observations, retained in case the user wants to retrieve the local entropy values of these. They're held in the order in which they were supplied in the addObservations(double[][], double[][]) functions.

      • destObservations

        protected double[][] destObservations
        The set of destination observations, retained in case the user wants to retrieve the local entropy values of these. They're held in the order in which they were supplied in the addObservations(double[][], double[][]) functions.

      • totalObservations

        protected int totalObservations
        Total number of observations supplied. Only valid after finaliseAddObservations() is called.

      • lastAverage

        protected double lastAverage
        Store the last computed average MI

      • miComputed

        protected boolean miComputed
        Track whether we've computed the average for the supplied observations yet

      • debug

        protected boolean debug
        Whether to report debug messages or not

      • timeDiff

        protected int timeDiff
        Time difference from the source to the destination observations (ie destination lags the source by this time: we compute I(source_{n}; dest_{n+timeDiff}). (Note that our internal sourceObservations and destObservations are adjusted so that there is no timeDiff between them).

      • vectorOfSourceObservations

        protected java.util.Vector<double[][]> vectorOfSourceObservations
        Storage for source observations supplied via addObservations(double[][], double[][]) type calls

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF -- Time difference between source and destination (0 by default). Must be >= 0.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:

        Parameters:

        propertyValue - value of the property

        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        public void setObservations(double[][] source,
                   double[][] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF for the channel measure. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series are certainly (multivariate) time-series for time-series measures such as transfer entropy, however may be simply a set of separate observations for the mutual information without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        source - series of multivariate observations for the source variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        destination - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • startAddObservations

        public void startAddObservations()

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[][] source,
                   double[][] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(); call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        source - series of multivariate observations for the source variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        destination - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:

        Specified by:

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:

        destination - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of steps from and including startTime to use

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination,
                   int startTime,
                   int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with, as a subset of the supplied arrays. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of steps from and including startTime to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate

        Sets the single set of observations to compute the PDFs from, where the source and destination observations are valid. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series are certainly time-series for time-series measures such as transfer entropy, however may be simply a set of separate observations for the mutual information without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        source - series of multivariate observations for the source variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        destination - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        sourceValid - series (with first indices the same as source) indicating whether the source at that index is valid.
        destValid - time series (with first indices the same as destination) indicating whether the destination at that index is valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • finaliseAddObservations

        public void finaliseAddObservations()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.

        This default implementation simply puts all of the observations into the sourceObservations and destObservations arrays. Usually child implementations will override this, call this implementation to perform the common processing, then perform their own processing.

        Specified by:
        finaliseAddObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Allow child classes to throw an exception if there is an issue detected specific to that calculator.

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a resampled distribution of what the MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate MI calculations.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples for permutations to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a resampled distribution of what the MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement a clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        We permute the source variable against the destination to be consistent with the description in EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int[][]) (though in theory this doesn't matter for this function call).

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int[] newOrdering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception

        Compute the mutual information if the first (source) variable were ordered as per the ordering specified in newOrdering.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of a shuffled source series here.

        This method is primarily intended for use in computeSignificance(int[][]) however has been made public in case users wish to access it.

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        Child implementations must only over-write lastAverage if newOrdering is null, which indicates that the original ordering should be used (making this equivalent to a call to InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.computeAverageLocalOfObservations()).

        Specified by:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        newOrdering - a specification of how to shuffle the source values to create a surrogate source time series. It is an array of length N (where would be the value returned by getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the surrogate MI score if the source values were shuffled as specified.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] newSourceObservations,
                                             double[] newDestObservations)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator
        Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        newSourceObservations - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index)
        newDestObservations - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • getLastAverage

        public double getLastAverage()
        Return the MI last calculated in a call to InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations() after the previous initialise() call.
        Specified by:
        getLastAverage in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Returns:
        the last computed average mutual information

      • getNumObservations

        public int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to setObservations(double[][], double[][]), addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (i.e. where a MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF is set).

        Specified by:
        getNumObservations in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if child class computes MI without explicit observations (e.g. MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian)

      • getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet

        public boolean getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet()
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Query whether the user has added more than a single observation set via the ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(), "addObservations" (defined by child interfaces and classes), ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() sequence.
        Specified by:
        getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        true if more than a single observation set was supplied

      • computeStartAndEndTimePairs

        public java.util.Vector<int[]> computeStartAndEndTimePairs(boolean[] sourceValid,
                                                  boolean[] destValid)
        Compute a vector of start and end pairs of time points, between which we have valid series of both source and destinations.

        Made public so it can be used if one wants to compute the number of observations prior to setting the observations.

        Parameters:
        sourceValid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid for the source;
        destValid - as described for sourceValid
        Returns:
        a vector for start and end time pairs of valid series of observations.
